is there a newbie guide for submitting html5lib-tests pull requests the Right Way?
jgraham: ^^
hsivonen, I assume the same process as web-platform-tests
Yeah, same process, but to html5lib-tests rather than web-platform-tests mostly
jgraham: so 1) fork repo on github, 2) pull your own fork, 3) create a branch in the local repo, 4) commit changes to branch, 5) ???
hi, is this valid html? http://jsfiddle.net/pef48j5e/
hsivonen: 5) Press the "create pull request" button in the GitHub UI
I want some content to be "centered and sized", and some other content to take the full width of the viewport
jgraham: OK. Should there be squashing before that?
hsivonen: Starting with a single commit is better, unless it's clearly logically seperate commits. Please don't squash after the initial submission though
(it upsets the code review tool)
my understanding of the lifetime of feature branches in the PR-based workflow is still hazy
jgraham: ok. that differs from the Gaia guideline
hsivonen: If you don't want to fork, you are welcome to have access to the main repo to push your branch
This is better in several ways (notably that other people can more easilly push commits to fix review issues)
jgraham: thanks. that kind of thing is why I haven't learned the PR-based workflow :-)
hsivonen: It's still a PR-based workflow
jgraham: oh
You just push the branch to the main repo rather than to your fork
so far, I've had too much write access to learn how the real workflow works
(under the covers it's actually even more similar than you would think given the UI)
jgraham: will the branch stay around forever or does it get flattened out somehow after the PR has been accepted?
jgraham: will future generations be able to laugh at my intermediate steps?
hsivonen: You can rebase+squash once the review is accepted and delete the review branch
jgraham: ok.
still doesn't grok how "everyone has a copy of all data" and "you can delete a branch" interact

hsivonen: Well the branch is only a pointer to the commits. So you can delete the pointer without deleting the commits. Then after some time (90 days by default) any commits that aren't reachable from a pointer are discarded. Of course if someone else has cloned the repo, they might still have a pointer to your commits locally and they could push those commits back upstream. So you can't guarantee that they have been expunged forevermore, but it's n
jgraham: you got cut off at "but it's no"
oh, git exposes gc behavior. boo
"but it's not a scenario that happens much in practice becase there usually isn't any reason to push old commits that have already been merged."
smaug____: Well that's a feature I think. The mercurial equivalent is either strip files or not actually deleting commits but marking them as hidden
I would expect gc-able stuff to not show up anywhere, certainly not in clones
so gc could run during cloning
I don't know if gc-able stuff does show up in clones, actually. I was thinking of the situation where someone had already cloned and the commits were de-referenced upstream.

annevk: why do we care about associated realms here
because otherwise it's unclear where the prototype comes from
annevk: we create an object. creating an object is something we do all over the place in the specs.
yeah, this is a pretty big problem
annevk: well we're not going to create constructors for everything we create objects for
annevk: so whatever our solution is, it has nothing to do with constructors
annevk: so again, i don't see how this affects the events issue
well for events constructors are nice because of the dictionary design
as spec authors have difficulty getting the prose right
IDL is much easier

Is this issue high priority for you? I'd prefer to wait until IDL is revamped. Hopefully then we have a better idea of how to define objects. Provided real effort is put into that

peoples!  can someone explain to me why the searchParams serialization algorithm detailed for URLSearchParams would be totally unaware of anything but ASCII?  seems like that nonsense just shouldn't be, for new APIs
jwalden: You mean http://url.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-urlencoded-serializer ?
jsbell: yes, that and http://url.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-urlencoded-byte-serializer
that algorithm can use any encoding but defaults to utf8
oh, am I misreading?  step 1 converts Unicode stuffs into byte arrays, then serialization individually converts each byte into +/percent-encoding/that code point?
yeah, i think so
hi Domenic! heads up that domenic.me/2014/02/14/the-revealing-constructor-pattern/ results in 404

jorendorff: bz says that Firefox is going to "progressively parse scripts, and possibly progressively bytecode-compile, and possibly progressively native-code-compile". Do you know how this will interact with the ES6 moduel loader?
Hixie_: what does "progressively" mean in these contexts?
did i delete the e-mail that explained that
ah, no, yoav explains it:
> If receiving multiple resources progressively provides better performance
> then having the server sending them one after the other, then the hint
> should be sent.
Hixie_: Hmm. It seems like there is a problem in the ES6 Loader design: that design requires parsing (the full module body) to succeed before starting work on dependencies
Hixie_: the normalize hook is called, for each import-declaration, after parsing --
seems like it is specified to NOT eagerly go after those dependencies before the first one is done loading
jorendorff: yeah, i've been trying to tell es-discuss this for like a month now
Hixie_: probably because if you *really* want that Loader to perform, you're not waiting around for all these round trips anyway
the server has to tell the app what it needs and push it -- which the model does kind of support
jorendorff: not really, unless you mean it supports it because the cache gets primed.
jorendorff: but in practice i don't think we can rely on servers like that
it "supports" it only in that it has appropriate hooks
jorendorff: i mean, it's been 24 years and people still can't set their mime types correctly
Hixie_: This is where I have trouble understanding what you're saying though
Hixie_: because if the client is to have any understanding beforehand of what is to be loaded... then it has to get that somewhere
from a manifest or "this needs that" declarations of some kind
sure. people are really good at making their servers serve up static files.
url -> file
or url -> cgi script -> file
it's when you have to configure the server that things get dicey
url -> file + configured metadata
url -> multiple files
url -> redirect, even, in many cases
"asset pipeline" stuff exists though
it's not seen as configuration by the people who have to put up with it
it's just the way their platform does things, and they play along with a few rules
for some people, sure
most people, though, i doubt will ever get this working
just like now some people have CDMs that manage mime types correctly, but most people just ship their files with bogus default types that apache ships with
but unlike with mime types, where browsers just ignore them, if we don't provide a way around this, that long tail will either not be able to use es6, or they'll have terrible performance.

jorendorff: in any case, this is all moot relative to the point i was talking about above. Even if you only have one module, how can you parse it like bz describes if it has to go through the ES6 module loader pipeline?
Hixie_: oh, it can speculatively parse all it wants to, just like HTML, right?
not if the browser doesn't see a single byte until the translate hook has returned
which happens after the entirety of the fetch hook
Hixie_: sure, if you play by the rules
Hixie_: you can either speculatively parse or not. if you do speculatively parse, you have to not get caught
like every other optimization
so basically anyone who uses an ES6 loader is going to see their performance drop off a cliff?
we should design this so that using this correctly and fully is completely compatible with the optimisations
e.g. using streams instead of promises
imho
that's fine with me
jorendorff: you or bz or something should tell es-discuss :-)
i don't think people there are listening to me anymore
is it actually specified anywhere that SVG elements in an HTML document are supposed to have the `innerHTML` property?
the interaction between svg and html is just super confusing and hard to keep track of
it's currently defined that they should not, iirc
well, blink and gecko both expose it, and applications depend on it
but unfortunately those applications break in safari
are there any methods that take 'any...' arguments and then later try to coerce that to a dictionary?
None that I know of
I am afraid to ask why you're asking that...
Domenic: to spec getContext()'s {alpha:false} feature which multiple browsers implement
Domenic: btw, is it intended that the WebIDL conversion algorithm for jsval to dict doesn't throw if passed a promise?
(it does if passed a Date or RegExp)
Hixie_: It's not intentional in that I don't believe anyone made a conscious decision
k
IMO Date and RegExp are the weird ones out ... Map, Set, Array, Error, etc. all don't throw either.
true
Array and Error are less magical than Map, Set, and Promise though
and those are the only old ones there
Eh, unclear. Array has some fun magic going on.
